text:
ROBYN: Today, as I said, we're
here with Jennifer Aaker, the General Atlantic Professor
at Stanford in the Graduate

School of Business. We'll be talking today with
Steve Clayton, the VP of Global Public Affairs and the chief
storyteller at Microsoft.

Among other things,
they're going to be talking about
Steve's journey in transforming the way
that Microsoft communicates

both internally
and with the world. And with that, we are
going to get started.

Thank you for being here,
both of you, and take it away. JENNIFER AAKER:
Thank you, Robyn. It's so wonderful to be here.

Among a few classes that I teach
at Stanford, Power of Story is one. And I think there is
no more popular guest

than Steve Clayton that
we can have here today. So I'm really excited
to talk with you, Steve. Thank you for being here.

Let's start with just the facts. You are among a couple
of titles that you have

and we'll talk a little
bit about that later. You are also the chief
storyteller officer at Microsoft.

So can you tell us a story
about how that role came to be and how you became part of it?

STEVE CLAYTON: Yeah, well,
first of all, thank you, Robyn and Jennifer. It's great to be here
and just amazing to see

how many people are excited
to hear about storytelling. So I hope we can do it
justice from the stories

here at Microsoft. But I'll tell you
a quick two part story of how I ended up
A, at Microsoft, and then,

B, in this job of
storytelling because I always like to start with the story. The fast version of the story
is about when I joined Microsoft

in '97. But I left University
I think in '91 or '92. And I went to work for
a company in the UK.

I'm originally from the UK,
despite this accent that sits mid-Atlantic these days. But I worked for a company
in the UK that many of you

will know. It was called Zeneca back then. It's now called AstraZeneca. Obviously, one of the
producers of a COVID vaccine.

But I worked in
the IT department at Zeneca straight
out of university. And in that IT
department at Zeneca,

we spent lots of time
working with Microsoft. We were one of the biggest
customers of Microsoft. And this is way back
25, 28 years ago

or something like that. And so I got to know lots
of people at Microsoft incredibly well.

And so much so about two
or three years into the job at Zeneca. I get a phone call
and I'm in the office

and I pick up the phone
and I said, hi, it's Steve. And the person on the
other end of the phone says, Steve, it's
Paul from Microsoft.

And he says, listen, I'm not
really supposed to do this. He says, but would you
be interested in a job at Microsoft?

And I said, well, I'm flattered. I would love to have
a job at Microsoft. He said, great. I'll put you in touch with
the HR team at Microsoft

and we'll get you
through the process. So I go through this
very long interview process and multiple different
rounds of interviews.

And ultimately, get offered
the job at Microsoft. And so I go back to Zeneca
on a Monday morning,

I go into my boss's
office and I say, hey, I've accepted
a job at Microsoft and I'm going to be
joining Microsoft.

And well, actually,
what I should have said earlier in the
story is every month, a group of people from
Zeneca from the IT department

would go to visit Microsoft
at the head office in a place called
Redding in England. And so that's how I'd got to
know the team at Microsoft very

well. So I walk into my boss's
office and I say, hey, I've accepted this
job at Microsoft. And my start date is
in a month's time.

And he says, we're
sorry to lose you. But let's just work through
this final month period and finish up your
projects here at Zeneca.

And so I had a month
left working at Zeneca. And during this month, we had
one of these regular visits

to the Microsoft
Office in Redding. And so I arrived at
the Microsoft Office. We have a day of meetings.

Meet with all of the
team at Microsoft. And then, we wrap up
the day of meetings. And as you do, you go to
the pub for a few drinks

after the meetings
because I like to say that all good stories
start or end in a pub. So I'm in the pub.

I'm with a friend from Zeneca. And the door to the pub opens. It's this beautiful country
pub it's called The Bull

in a place called Sonning. If you ever find yourself in
that area, The Bull at Sonning is a fabulous pub on the
banks of the River Thames.

The door to the pub opens. I'm stood at the bar
with my colleague from Zeneca, who's
also called Steve.

And in walks this
guy called Paul. Paul had made the
original phone call to ask me to apply for the job.

But Paul had not been involved
in the interview process at all. And so he sees the two of us,
walks straight up to the bar,

and stretches out his hand
in the classic handshake move to the other
Steve and says,

congratulations on the job. And the other Steve looks at
Paul and looks at me and says, I think you mean him.

And in that moment,
Paul realized that he had phoned the
wrong Steve originally. He'd meant to phone
the other Steve.

But worse than that, Microsoft
had hired the wrong Steve. And this is a
genuine true story.

Literally, Microsoft
hired the wrong Steve. They were trying
to hire Steve Clark and they hired Steve Clayton.

Anyway, so Paul and I
decided that we would keep this a secret for a while. And by a while, we
mean about 18 years.

So about four years ago
our chief HR officer invited me to come and speak
to all of the HR professionals

at Microsoft. 1,500 people in a giant hotel
ballroom here in Seattle.

And I thought, this is it. The best of the best
of Microsoft's HR team. This is the time to unload
the wrong Steve story.

And so I told them that story of
how I got hired into Microsoft. So that's the first
very quick story.

The second story about
the chief storyteller job, I'll try and do even quicker
is I had been working in the UK

for about 11-- probably 11 or 12
years and I started to write a blog
about the company

because I was very frustrated
with the public perception of Microsoft. And this is in the
late '90s early 2000s.

And the blog got quite popular. It wasn't my day job. It was a hobby. My day job was
selling and talking

about Microsoft technology. And a couple of
years into writing this blog I got a phone call
from a guy called Frank Shaw.

Frank runs communications
for Microsoft. Runs all of PR and
all of communications. Phones me up one
evening in London.

It was a wet Tuesday evening. I remember vividly. I picked up the phone again
and this time the voice said,

Steve, it's Frank Shaw. And I knew who Frank was
and I thought, oh dear. This is it.

This is the day I'm
going to lose my job. I'm going to get fired because
of something I did on my blog.

And my voice went
up a few octaves and I sort of said, well,
how can I help you, Frank? And he said, well, I think
it's how I can help you.

He said, I think you
should come to Seattle and do that as a full time
job, that blogging thing.

So that's what I did
just about 11 years ago. Moved to Seattle and
began this journey

as chief storyteller
of Microsoft. JENNIFER AAKER: OK, so for all
of you who are joining late,

one of the key insights here is
all good stories start and end with a good pub or a good
drink at many different types

of pubs. Tell us a little bit
more about your mandate. So you get to Microsoft,
you have this mandate.

One of the things that
I find is so interesting is how you actually
build a skill.

And so take us through chapter
by chapter what you did.

STEVE CLAYTON: Yeah, well when
I first showed up here, it was--

the first, I would
say, few months was a little bit daunting. Because remember, I don't--

I came from an IT background. My profession my-- what
I studied at University was a classic sort of IT core.

So I didn't really have a
profession in journalism or writing or
communications, but I did have a passion for it.

And so when I showed
up, my job was what we-- at least for the first
few years is what we call an individual contributor.

So I was just-- it was just me. And then, I got to
grow a team, which we can talk about, hopefully.

But for the first
few years, my job was really to be a
spokesperson and a blogger

and a so-called
evangelist for the company all around technology
and innovation.

I really didn't have much of
an idea of how I would do that. So what I started to do
in the first few weeks here in Seattle-- and
we have a huge campus

with about 55,000
employees spread across this beautiful green
campus up here in Seattle.

And I just started to go around
and interview people and just talk to people I knew or
knew of and asked them

if I can have 30
minutes of their time and just understand what
they were working on. And then, every
person I spoke with,

at the end of the
interview, I said to them, who would be five other
people that you would recommend I would go and talk to?

And so within two
months, I'd conducted about 45 or 50 interviews
with just a group of incredible, talented
people at Microsoft

in all kinds of different roles. And then, I wrote a
series of blog posts.

So we set up a new blog. We closed my old
blog down and set up a new blog that was
called Next at Microsoft.

And we got ready to
launch this blog. And I wrote five
launch blog posts all about these interesting
people that I'd met.

And then, I spoke to
my manager at the time and I said, OK, we're going
to launch the blog next week.

And he said to me, great, have
you run all of these blog posts past the PR team,
and have you run them all past the legal department?

And I said, no, I didn't
realize I had to do that. And he said, well,
you're going to be speaking on behalf
of the company,

so you really ought to do that. And I thought, this isn't
what I signed up for. And so I phoned a friend.

I phoned my friend Frank, who'd
basically asked me to move me and my family 5,000 miles.

And I remember going home,
actually, the night before and saying to my
wife, I said, I think we might have to
go back to the UK

because I think
this job isn't what I thought it was going to be. But I phoned Frank
and I said, listen,

I would love to
just chat with you about some challenges I have. And I sat down with him
in a pub, unsurprisingly,

a place called The Attic in
Madison Park over a beer. And I said, listen, Frank.

JENNIFER AAKER: I'm so sorry. Let me interrupt. The first one was called-- I'm going to make a
list of these, Steve. The first one was called
the bull in the pub.

STEVE CLAYTON: The
Bull in Sonning. S- O- N- N- I- N- G. This
one is called The Attic

in Madison Park. JENNIFER AAKER: I'm taking
rigorous notes for everyone. Keep going. STEVE CLAYTON: OK, so
I sit down with Frank

and I basically said,
listen, I love this job. I'm happy to be here. But I have this real challenge
is I've written this content

and it's very much written
in an authentic in my voice and I want to publish. I said, and I don't-- I didn't realize
I had to run this

by the PR department
and the legal department and I'm worried that that's
going to water down the message and take away the authenticity.

And he looked at me and he
just said, Steve, just publish. He said, just go
ahead and publish.

He says, I brought you
here to tell stories-- tell the stories. And in that moment-- and it puts the hairs up
on the back of my neck now.

He gave me this permission to
just say go and tell stories on behalf of Microsoft. And I always like to say, what's
the worst that can happen?

I could get fired. And I'll come back to that. It's a story I tell my team. I have this catchphrase
I give them around that.

But anyway, so we started to-- I started to build up
this body of content. And then, the next few
steps in the journey

that was relatively
successful, so much so that Frank a few years later
came along and said, hey, I think you should
take on a team

and run our team that--
we had a website that used to be called News
Center, which really was just a vehicle for releasing
press releases on Microsoft.

And he said, you should
think about how do we want to evolve News Center. And so we started to change
how we did deliver the news.

And then, there was this
pivotal moment of which I'm sure some people will
remember when Snowfall,

the story the New
York Times wrote, John Branch wrote this
incredible 13,000 word story

about a tragic avalanche that
happened not far from Seattle, actually, that killed
a number of skiers.

And the story was incredible. It won a Pulitzer Prize. But the way it was delivered
on the web-- and this

is probably seven or
eight years ago now. But it still stands
the test of time. If you haven't seen it, go
and take a look at Snowfall.

And its delivery of a story
digitally was phenomenal. And I remember, again,
talking to Frank on that day,

albeit not in a pub. And we said, this is it. This is the future
of storytelling. And actually, this
is the game that we

should get into is telling
our stories in this way. Not just as a dry
press release, but as immersive content with real
journalistic skill sets applied

to the storytelling. And so we started
to build this team. We launched our own--

there's another story about we
created our first owned story, as we called it, that was called
88 Acres about three or four

months after that that
shamelessly ripped off Snowfall. And we were
shameless about that.

And then, that just
began this journey of storytelling becoming a real
discipline and a profession

of the company. And there are a
few other chapters, but I'll pause,
though, because that's the first couple of chapters.

JENNIFER AAKER: Great,
good place to pause. Let me sprinkle on a couple
of comments from the audience.

One is from Katia, who just-- she argues, sounds very similar
to a brand ambassador role.

How you might think
of chief storyteller. And then, so maybe
a little comment about how you think
of brand versus story.

But also she was
wondering about, how do you make sure
to keep your voice so

authentic to Microsoft? You were certainly empowered
at the beginning by Frank.

But how do you maintain that
as you build out the team? Do you want to take
one or both of those? STEVE CLAYTON: Yeah,
I'll take both of them.

I think the brand one is a
really good observation is the work I do and
increasingly the work

I've done over
the last few years have become more and
more tied to brand. And I think it is about
being a brand ambassador.

But being a brand ambassador
genuinely for the brand and for the company
versus a brand ambassador

for the products of the company. And I think that those are two
distinctly different things, and neither of them are bad.

But all of the work I've done,
really, over the last 10 years has been about building
brand awareness

and be a brand ambassador,
if you want to call it that. A chief storyteller, brand
ambassador, for the company.

So it's very much been about-- and that became, in some
ways, an easier job. About seven-- six
and a half years ago,

we changed the mission
statements at Microsoft. Satya Nadella became our
CEO about seven years ago--

seven and a half years
ago and relatively early into Satya's tenure, we
changed the mission statement

to be to empower every
person and every organization on the planet to achieve more. And what that gave us
was-- as a storyteller,

it gave us this license to
say, we can go and tell stories in service of that mission,
which we didn't really

have before. We'd had mission
statements as a company. For example, the first
mission statement of Microsoft back in '75 was
to put a PC on every desk

and in every home, which
is a noble mission, but it doesn't really give you
a lot of license or air cover

for telling stories about
brand and about the impact that brand has on the world. Whereas, empower every
person and every organization

on the planet to
achieve more gives you a huge amount of
landscape to go and tell stories about the
impact the company

has and didn't really require me
to go and talk about products. Not to say I don't like
our products, but it's--

hopefully, that
answered that question. JENNIFER AAKER:
Yeah, definitely. And actually, Sid had a related
question to Katia's which is--

can you talk a
little bit about-- as a brand ambassador,
as a storyteller, how do you walk that
line between what

is truthful and authentic
to Microsoft and--

but also kind of representing
this larger higher purpose? And I think what they're getting
at is we're at a moment of time

where misinformation and making
things look prettier than they

are is something that
seems to be something that people are grappling with. How does that fit
into your job or how

do you think about these
kind of issues between truth versus the stories that
are being shared internally

outside to the world? STEVE CLAYTON: I think this
might sound a bit trite,

but I think about it a lot
and I don't think about it. Because I think I'm fortunate
that I work at a company

where we've spent
a lot of time very intentionally over the last,
I would say, 15 years really

thinking about trust and
how do we build trust? And how do we build trust
with all audiences, consumers,

policymakers, regulators? And the truth is,
ironically, we haven't always had that in the
history of the company.

But I would say that we are in a
position where we do have that. And it's not by accident.

It's by putting a lot of
energy and work and effort into just being
truthful and to being honest into accepting
mistakes and to talking

about where we need to
improve and to not hiding the facts from people. A great example
recently was there

was a huge cyber attack that
became known as Solarwinds. And Microsoft played a big
part in both a good way,

but also in a way where
we were attacked ourselves from a cyber attack. And what we could have done
is hidden that information

and not talked about it
because people generally don't want to talk about the
fact that they've been hacked. And Microsoft technically
wasn't hacked.

I won't bore you with
the technical details. But we were incredibly
public about it because it was important that
people got to hear about that.

That people
understood the impact of it, companies
and individuals, that people got to
protect themselves. And so it's--

I think one of the
things that I think you're getting at in
that question is just around how do you--

I don't really think about it
so much as walk in the line. I think about it as just
being honest, being authentic,

and telling the truth. And then, you never
will feel yourself on the tightrope having to
walk that line because you

can go home at night and
say, we told the truth. We told the right story. And we're not trying to
dance on some knife's edge.

JENNIFER AAKER: Fantastic. I want to go back to the mandate
and the chapters that unfolded.

One specific question, talk
about how you built the team. So for example,
with some companies

that I know that build out
story as a core capacity. They go from an
individual contributor
to then having a writer. And then, having a filmmaker. And then to kind of parse that.

And in particular, Arun-- I think that's how
you pronounce it. I'm not sure. He asked, with the
rise of podcast,

if you had to go back and
do it over again right now-- if you were in your
position right now trying to build out
a team, can you also

talk about the role of a
podcast versus script or blog? STEVE CLAYTON: Yeah, so in terms
of how we built out the team,

there were a group of
people already on the team that I inherited. This new sense of
team who were all came from an
editorial background.

But really, I think one
of the pivotal moments is that when we
decided to really get into our own content.

And back to that story
I mentioned 88 Acres. The story behind that,
you'll be pleased to know, started in a pub.

So there was a pub on Microsoft
campus that's called Boardwalk. And I met--

I had a meet-- there was a
social gathering at Boardwalk several years ago. And I ran into this guy Rob.

And he said, oh, I've got this
great story for you, Steve. And it was all about-- he said,
it's all about real estate
and facilities at Microsoft. And I said, come on, Rob. I said, real estate facilities?

We're talking about super
cool technology here and you want me to go and
tell a story about buildings. And he said, no, I think
you should go and explore

this story. And so I did. I went and met this guy
called Darryl Smith who basically managed our buildings
and ensured that power came on

and lighting came on and that
was water to the buildings and stuff like that. And Darryl, true to Rob, he
had this incredible story

about how our entire
campus had been digitized. And so I will get to the
answer to the question here.

I'm building up to it. So I went and met Darryl. And it's like, wow, this
is an incredible story. So we packaged up the
story, my team and I.

And we took it in
our media agency. And we took it to three
very large media outlets

that I won't name. But every one of
them said, no, we're not interested in this story
because there's no news here so we'll pass on it.

So that was the point we
assigned one of our writers at the time to say,
well, we're going

to go do the story ourselves. And we wrote this 3,000
word story called 88 Acres and we published it.

And within two days, it
was incredibly successful by any measure. It had quarter of a
million page views.

We didn't put any
paid media behind it. It generated a whole
different story. It generated within a week
a $10 million sales pipeline

from this story. And so that was the
moment where we said, wow, this is something we
have to go and invest in.

My boss Frank, and actually,
our CMO at the time, still CMO Chris Capossela said,
let's go and invest in this.

So I began to hire
journalists and editors. And so I hired a guy
called Michael Wann, who

was previously the managing
editor of msnbc.com. He ran a 100 person newsroom.

And he came to run
and built a team and still runs a team
that is our storytelling--

our News Center, if you like,
evolution of our News Center. The short answer to
the question, I guess, is we began to hire people
from journalistic backgrounds

because we really started
to think like and act like journalists. But then, we started to add
different skill sets to that.

So we added video capability. We started to think a lot about
photography, both of which we contracted in.

We didn't have as
full time positions. But the real answer to the
question, I think, is this. Is that what we hired for is--
and what I always hire for,

even in my team now, is
I hire for curiosity. You want people who are
curious about the world.

People who are going to
walk down a busy high street and notice the one thing
that's out of place

and say, why is
that out of place? And they're going to go and
explore it and investigate it and figure out why?

And so, really, what we hire
for and the team we build is people who are just
passionately curious

about the world, but
also tend to have a great background in writing.

And then, to the question
from Arun around podcasts. I have a little bit of
a love hate view of--

I love podcasts. I literally listened to two on
the way into work this morning. I listen to The Daily and I
listen to the Politico podcast.

But I have this view
of corporate podcasts, I think, are a lot
more difficult. And the reason is
because there are

lots of really great podcasts
out in the world already. And so I-- we have a few
Microsoft, one of which

I'm a huge fan of. Our CTO is a guy
called Kevin Scott, and he has a podcast
called Behind the Tech.

And I think it's fascinating
because he brings a unique point of view on that.

If I went back in time and said,
would I do things differently? Would I do a podcast? I think the answer is
maybe, but I probably

wouldn't do a Microsoft podcast. Because as much as
I love this company and I think we play an
important role in the world,

I'm just not sure that people
wake up in the morning and say, oh, you know what I want? I need a podcast from Microsoft.

I think what they maybe do
want or would benefit from is hearing from voices at
Microsoft in other podcasts,

whether that's with
Kara Swisher, where we-- our president Brad Smith did
a great podcast with her.

Or when we show up on
places like the daily. And so I love
podcasts, but I'm--

I think they have to-- there
has to be very careful thought about corporate podcasts.

Because to do them well-- and we did-- we actually did try
one a few years ago on my team. It was called Dot Future,
and it's still out there,

and it's still a great podcast. But we put a lot
of money into it. Did we get the ROI? I'm not sure we did because it
hasn't existed and continued.

JENNIFER AAKER: Right. Did you say dark--
what was it called? STEVE CLAYTON: Dot Future.

JENNIFER AAKER: Dot Future. STEVE CLAYTON:
microsoft.com/podcast. It sits on that web page.

JENNIFER AAKER: OK, now
Steve, if you titled that, all good stories start
and end with a good pub.

And here are the list of our
pubs, which Robin, by the way, is pulling together
and I think linking.

This morning just
paid for itself. All right, so talk
a little bit-- we've got a great question
about how the story has evolved.

You've started to take
us through the chapters, building out the
team, et cetera, when you got to Microsoft.

Do you want to talk a little
bit about how the story has evolved, especially aligned
with this higher purpose that's

also evolved since
Satya has taken over? STEVE CLAYTON:
Yeah, I think if I

look at all of the
work I've done, I would say the work
that I'm most proud of and has been the most
interesting from a storytelling

point of view has been
the last six or seven years around a lot of
internal storytelling,

actually, at the company. Because Satya Nadella became
CEO, I think, February 4th, 2014.

So seven and a
bit years ago now. And I was involved in telling
the story around that. Even Satya's announcement we
did in a very different way.

The way that you would
normally do something like that around announcing
a CEO of a Fortune--

I'll call it a Fortune
Five company, let me put it that way, is that
you would write a press release and you would send
it across the wires

to AP and Bloomberg and Reuters. And then, you would
sit back and you would field the set of
questions from the media.

And we said, we're
not going to do that. We are going to create
a website, which we did at the time. Microsoft.com/ceo.

It was this beautiful website. It had a video of Steve
Ballmer, or outgoing CEO. It had a video of Bill Gaetz.

It had a video of John Thompson,
our then chairman and a video of Satya. The video of Satya was a walk
and talk interview with me

that I'd shot with him three
days before we announce him. And it was this three
minute-- three to four minute

great discussion instead
of the traditional let's sit in two chairs
and have two gentlemen talk

to each other, we did
this walk and talk thing. Anyway, we basically
announced the CEO in a way that nobody has ever
done, so much so

that the Financial Times
wrote a story and said, Microsoft is doing
our job for us. And we wish they wouldn't.

And that began this
journey of us really thinking about how
storytelling can help to drive

culture change in the company. About a few months into
Satya's tenure as CEO, we created what we call the
set of cultural attributes

of the company. And I'll come back to those. And then, we created this
new mission statement. And then, a small group at the
company in the CEO's office

in communications with
my team and my boss and a few folks in our HR
team really got together

and became this what we
call the culture cabinet who work to say how are we
going to use storytelling

and communications in
a not nefarious way, in a very obvious way, to change
the culture of this company.

And so, as an example I
brought some props today. One of the first things
that we wanted to--

Satya was very keen to change
was shift this culture to what, as many of you will, I'm sure,
know intimately, Carol Dweck.

Carol Dweck's book Mindset
has been almost the foundation of the culture
change at Microsoft.

So for folks who don't
know Carol Dweck, her book on mindset
is phenomenal. So we wanted to launch
this idea of growth mindset

to Microsoft, where, frankly,
we didn't have a growth mindset. And we said, well,
how are we going

to do this with an
audience that is going to be very cynical
